ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We pretty much just had a live lecture on zoom, which the professor then posted to canvas as a recording.
I also attended a weekly discussion section.
Lectures were also recorded

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really learned a lot in this class. It presented a wholly different view on consumer and firm behavior compared to intro micro. Everything was modeled very mathematically and very rigorous, and it was awesome to see what properties became apparent after this careful modeling. We also did a lot with auctions and mechanism design, which is very abstract but super interesting if you can manage to get your head around it.
I gained an understanding of microeconomic theory.
The theory of the consumer, theory of the firm, markets, welfare theorems, auctions, mechanism design, information economics
Math, working with vectors, introduction to economic models
In-depth mathematical proofs of economic concepts and theories

Deep ground up analysis of a variety of concepts in microeconomics, including and not limited to:

Demand and individual consumer (indirect/direct) utilities and preferences
Supply and the mathematics modeling of a marketplace
Mechanism Design
Auction Theory

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course's strengths are probably that the class is small so that it is easy to engage with the professor, and the lecture notes are very clear, and move along with a textbook, which helps a lot.
This course, despite a small class size, is pure lecture. Engaging students more in class, like by having them work through practice problems, would be helpful.

Very mathematically rigorous course, which is good for those choosing to take this course. Perhaps more routine computations as exercises or during lecture would be helpful. The two pset drops were very helpful, as well as the fact that psets were graded on a 0-3 scale (eliminated stress over minor details, which was really nice).

As someone not particularly fluent with math prior to enrolling, the math 120 pre-requisite is a little bit misleading. In fact, most of my time I spent learning the math itself using other resources. Having finished the course, I dont recommend taking this until after math 250 or the math 230 sequence unless you want to spend a lot of time learning math unrelated to Econ.

Strengths: The course was organized and was run in a timely efficient matter. The expectations were pretty straightforward in terms of weekly psets and a midterm/final.
Weaknesses: It is unclear what is expected of students in terms of how to write and structure proofs. There were no clear guidelines or instructions given at the beginning of the course and there was little feedback on psets to indicate how students were doing.

Strengths: Very in depth and proof-centric. There is a continuous logical progression to the course materials.

Weakness: It is sometimes difficult to grasp why we would like to explore some particular concept until after the fact.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the professor's style of teaching (using a stylus and a tablet) made the fact that it was online very negligible - the class was easy to follow from that perspective, and I don't think I can suggest a way to improve the class in this regards.
Online classes were fine.
Recording lectures and section are very helpful

Office hours was helpful. Moreover, I never attended live lecture simply because the pace of the class was too fast for me - having the option to pause recorded lectures to take notes was extremely helpful.
I think the course succeeded in teaching to a virtual audience of students; I think the atmosphere between students could be improved (i.e. avenues for the students to co-discuss)

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course if you thought the intro economics courses were extremely slow and superficial. If you love abstract, proof-based math and have the patience for rigorous application of it, then this course is perfect for you. If not, it may turn into a nightmare.
I would not recommend this course. The course material was arcane, and although it was at times interesting, it just wasn't a very engaging class.

ECON 125 covers genuinely difficult topics, but does so at a pace that should be feasible for most Economics students. Unfortunately, I found the lectures to be unclear at times and learned the majority of the content through reading the textbook on my own. This class also struggles from similar frustrations of many classes (the professor uses different notation from the text book, the problem sets have unsolvable errors, TA hours are spent learning corollary topics rather than clarifying lecture).  Ultimately the course is not recommendable, but is still somewhat manageable, with straightforward exams and decent organization.
Should only be taken by people with sufficient command of concepts from introductory economics. Experience in mathematics is not enough.

Yes if interested in a much more solid foundation of microeconomics, but I recommend you take either math230/231 before or introductory analysis or related courses that cover beginner topics in point-set topology and analysis beforehand, as you need to use the notions of continuity, convexity, etc. to describe agent behavior in microeconomics.
If youre comfortable with working with math and vectors and are looking for a more rigorous introduction to micro theory, yes.

This is an extremely difficult proof-based courses and I would honestly not recommend this course to another student unless you have a strong desire to spend hours studying economic proofs. The course moves at a fairly fast pace and there are high expectations for students to learn a lot on their own. The psets and exams in this course are also very difficult, even if you understand most of the lectures. At the end of the day, not sure what utility this course will provide.
Yes, I would recommend this course to other mathematically inclined students who are interested in economics as a subject, rather than as a class to fill course requirements.
